thread.title: Joseph Parker's stablemates expected to headline boxing events in Australia and Poland
thread.title_full: Joseph Parker's stablemates expected to headline boxing events in Australia and Poland

author: DUNCAN JOHNSTONE
title: Joseph Parker's stablemates expected to headline boxing events in Australia and Poland
text:
Joseph Parker's stablemates expected to headline boxing events in Australia and Poland DUNCAN JOHNSTONE Last updated 05:00, October 16 2015 HANNAH PETERS/GETTY IMAGES 
Rising Australian welterweight boxer Jeff Horn, left, is expected to headline Duco fight promotions in his home country in the near future. 
Breakthrough boxing broadcasting deals in Australia and Poland are set to give Joseph Parker's stablemates exposure in their home countries â€“ as well as open doors for fight promotions there. 
World class Australian welterweight Jeff Horn and Parker's regular sparring partner, Nigerian-born, Poland-raised heavyweight Izu Ugonoh, are seen as increasingly valuable property that promoters Duco Boxing are eager to maximise. 
Horn, WBO #7, IBF #12, WBA #13 was fighting Argentina's Alfredo Rodolfo Blanco on Parker's undercard in Auckland on Thursday night with that fight beamed into Australia on Fox Sports. 
And Ugonoh's clash with Ghana's Ibrahim Labaran was broadcast in Poland on Polsat TV. 
The heavyweight fight was sanctioned with the interim WBO Oceania and WBA Africa titles on the line and a win for Ugonoh could take the unbeaten fighter into the top 15 rankings with both respected organisations. 
Duco boss Dean Lonergan revealed they had secured a deal with Fox Sports that would see Horn headline promotions in Australia and there was an appetite for the same sort of long-term deal with Ugonoh in Poland. 
Rather than fighting in the shadow of Parker, the WBO #6, WBA #13, WBC #14 heavyweight, it was time for Horn and Ugonoh to headline their own promotions. 
"Just as we have done with Joseph in New Zealand, the opportunity is now there for Jeff and Uzu to do their thing in their own countries," Lonergan said. 
It also gives the New Zealand company an invaluable foothold in both countries. They are keen to revitalise the Australian scene in particular. 
Parker won't feature on the Australian and Poland promotions with his ties linked to headlining New Zealand events but also pushing into bigger markets. Ad Feedback 
Lonergan has just returned form a lengthy trip to Europe mixing business with pleasure and believes it's an area where Parker's increasing profile can be utilised. 
Lonergan will attend the WBO conference in Florida at the end of the month and continue to build the American contacts for Parker in the biggest and most lucrative fight zone. 
Parker fought in Germany and the United States last year. He will start 2016 with a January fight in Samoa but push further afield during the year. - Stuff
